overview: Beginning 1/1/2026, this bill requires pharmacy technicians to be registered. [1] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. [1] The measure specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [1]
appropriations: This bill does not contain a legislative appropriation. [1] It establishes a registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] The measure also specifies that any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided legislative documents do not contain any assumptions, cost estimation methods, or data sources used to calculate financial projections for this measure. [1] No comparable programs or historical budgets are referenced for the calculation of financial impact. [1] The fiscal impact is based solely on the fee and fine amounts stated in the bill. [1]
agency_impact: The board of pharmacy is granted the authority to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [1] The board may also fine, suspend, or revoke any registration for any cause prescribed by this chapter. [1] Additionally, the board shall adopt rules to define the qualifications and functions of the registered pharmacy technician. [1]
economic_impact: The primary economic effect is a registration fee for a pharmacy technician which shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Additionally, any person who violates the provisions of the chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1] The documents do not detail any expected cost savings or other benefits to the community. [1]
policy_impact: This measure amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by requiring that no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid registration issued by the board beginning January 1, 2026. [1] It modifies existing law by specifying that the supervising registered pharmacist shall be responsible for the actions of the registered pharmacy technician. [1] The bill also adds a new definition for "Registered pharmacy technician" to the statutes. [1]
revenue_sources: Revenue to support this measure will be generated from a registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [1] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Additional revenue may be generated from fines, as any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1]
six_year_fiscal_implications: Beginning January 1, 2026, this measure will generate revenue for the state. [1] A registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) is established for each pharmacy technician. [1] Each registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, establishing a recurring biennial revenue stream. [1] Potential revenue may also be generated from fines for violations, which range from $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) to $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] The provided documents do not include projections on the number of pharmacy technicians who will register. [1] There is no information regarding necessary staffing changes or other recurring expenses related to the administration of this registration program. [1] Therefore, a detailed six-year fiscal projection cannot be accurately calculated based on the available information. [1] The initial revenues from registration would be collected for the biennium ending December 31, 2027. [1] The bill does not outline any plans for program expansion. [1] All proceedings for denial, suspension, fine, or revocation of a registration shall be conducted pursuant to chapter 91, which may have associated administrative costs. [1]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure will have a positive impact on operating revenues. [1] The State will collect a registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Additional, non-recurring revenue may be collected from fines of not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1]
capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not indicate any capital expenditures related to this measure. [1] No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure are mentioned. [1] The measure focuses on registration and regulation, not capital improvements. [1]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The fiscal implications after six years will consist of ongoing biennial revenue from the collection of the pharmacy technician registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Since each registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, the fee collection is a recurring event. [1] The provided documents do not contain information regarding the long-term sustainability of this funding or the projected number of registered technicians. [1]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [1]
fte_positions: The provided legislative documents do not specify the addition or modification of any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions. [1] There is no mention of new roles required to administer the registration program. [1] The bill does not address staffing changes. [1]
appropriations_changes: No appropriations are specified in this bill. [1] Therefore, there are no appropriations to modify or change from any previous versions. [1] The bill focuses on establishing fees and fines rather than allocating funds. [1]
funding_sources_changes: The bill establishes new revenue sources through registration fees and fines. [1] No previous funding sources were identified, so there are no changes in the method of funding to report. [1] The bill does not shift funding between general and special funds. [1]
department_impact: The bill assigns new regulatory responsibilities to the board of pharmacy. [1] There is no mention of a change in which department is responsible for expending appropriations. [1] The bill does not shift responsibilities from one department to another. [1]
reports_required: The bill requires a pharmacist-in-charge to notify the board, in writing, within ten days if a registered pharmacy technician is suspected to have violated any law or regulation. [1] If any danger to the public health or safety exists, the notification must be made immediately. [1] Any other registered pharmacist with such knowledge or suspicion must also notify the board. [1]
pilot_program: This bill does not create a pilot program for pharmacy technician registration; it establishes a permanent requirement. [1] The bill does state that the board may approve pilot and demonstration research projects for innovative applications in the practice of pharmacy. [1] However, the core of this legislation is the creation of a mandatory registration system. [1]
sunset_date: The provided legislative documents do not contain a sunset date for the program or the bill. [1] The registration requirement for pharmacy technicians appears to be permanent. [1]
effective_date: This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [1] There is no mention of a defective effective date in any previous version. [1]
